tn.text: It is unclear how long Moses and Aaron waited until they went to see Pharoah.
This is a celebration to worship Yahweh.
Pharaoh uses this question to show that he does not recognize Yahweh as a legitimate god. AT: "I do not know Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why should I ... let Israel go?
tn.text: Pharaoh uses this question to state that he has no interest in obeying Yahweh or in letting the Israelites go to worship him. AT: "He is nothing to me and I will not let Israel go!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The words "his voice" represent the words God spoke. AT: "listen to what he says" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a term also used for the Israelites' God or Yahweh.
Here "sword" represents war or an attack by enemies. AT: "or cause our enemies to attack us" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: why are you taking the people from their work?
tn.text: Pharaoh uses this question to express his anger towards Moses and Aaron for taking the Israelites away from their work. AT: "stop distracting the people from doing their work!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"slave drivers" These were Egyptians whose job was to force the Israelites to do hard work. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:01:11|1:11]].
The word "you" in these verses is plural and refers to the taskmasters and foremen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"slave drivers." These were Egyptians whose job was to force the Israelites to do hard work. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:01:11|1:11]].

tn.ref: I will no longer give you any straw ... get straw wherever you can find it
tn.text: The word "you" in these verses is plural and refers to the Israelite people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "yourselves" emphasizes that the Egyptians will no longer help them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: your workload will not be reduced
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "you must continue to make the same number of bricks as before"
This is an exaggeration used to show the extra effort Israel made to meet Pharaoh's demands. AT: "a wide area" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"slave drivers" These were Egyptians whose job was to force the Israelites to do hard work. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:01:11|1:11]].
the part of a plant that is left over after harvest

tn.ref: Why have you not produced all the bricks required of you ... in the past?
tn.text: The taskmasters used this question to show they were angry with the lack of bricks. AT: "You are not producing enough bricks, either yesterday or today, as you did in the past!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"complained"

tn.ref: they are still telling us, 'Make bricks!'
tn.text: Here "they" refers to the Egyptian taskmasters.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "when Pharaoh told them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a very large house that a king lives in.
The Egyptians responded to the Israelites the same way they would respond to a foul odor. AT: "you have caused them to hate us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: have put a sword in their hand to kill us
tn.text: Here "a sword" represents an opportunity to destroy enemies. AT: "have given them a reason to kill us" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Lord, why have you caused trouble for this people?
tn.text: This question shows how disappointed he was that the Egyptians were treating the Israelites even more harshly now. AT: "Lord, I am sorry that you have caused this trouble for this people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why did you send me in the first place?
tn.text: This question shows how disappointed Moses was that God had sent him to Egypt. AT: "I wish you had never sent me here!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: to speak to him in your name
tn.text: The word "name" here represents the message of God. AT: "to give him your message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
